message.content:
<<<api>>>: ImageIO
<<<code>>>: You can use a custom mechanism to stream images by reading the bytes into a buffer until it reaches a specified byte or sequence of bytes, at which point you can read the image out of the buffer. Here's an example:

Server code:
```java
while (true) {
    Socket sock = s.accept();
    System.out.println("Connection");
    OutputStream out = sock.getOutputStream();
    while (!sock.isClosed()) {
        BufferedImage img = // get image
        ByteArrayOutputStream baos = new ByteArrayOutputStream();
        ImageIO.write(img, "jpg", baos);
        byte[] imageBytes = baos.toByteArray();
        out.write(imageBytes);
        Thread.sleep(100);
    }
    System.out.println("Closed");
}
```

Client code:
```java
Socket s = new Socket(InetAddress.getByName("localhost"), 1998);
InputStream in = s.getInputStream();
byte[] buffer = new byte[1024];
int bytesRead;
ByteArrayOutputStream baos = new ByteArrayOutputStream();
while ((bytesRead = in.read(buffer)) != -1) {
    baos.write(buffer, 0, bytesRead);
    if (isEndOfImage(buffer)) {
        byte[] imageBytes = baos.toByteArray();
        ByteArrayInputStream bais = new ByteArrayInputStream(imageBytes);
        BufferedImage img = ImageIO.read(bais);
        // do something useful with the image
        baos.reset();
    }
}

private boolean isEndOfImage(byte[] buffer) {
    // Implement your logic to detect the end of an image
    // For example, check for a specific byte or sequence of bytes
    return false;
}
```

In this example, the server writes the image bytes directly to the output stream, and the client reads the bytes into a buffer. The `isEndOfImage` method is used to determine if the buffer contains the complete image. If it does, the image bytes are converted to a `BufferedImage` using `ImageIO.read` and you can then do something useful with the image.
